title: Police 'ask people for ID to cross London bridge'
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

The Metropolitan Police have come under fire online for ‘authoritarian’ behaviour after allegedly making ‘indiscriminate ID checks’ in London yesterday.

Footage uploaded to Twitter allegedly shows officers requesting ID from people attempting to cross Lambeth Bridge on Tuesday, with one onlooker claiming the atmosphere was ‘tense and intimidating’.

The incident comes as police ordered Extinction Rebellion to stop all protests in London and revealed that more than 1,400 protesters had been arrested.

The Met has denied that officers have been briefed to check IDs, claiming they had been ‘proactively engaging with individuals crossing’ to ensure Extinction Rebellion’s plans to bring London to a standstill did not work.

However, Green Party candidate for Hackney North and Stroke Newington Alex Armitage, who uploaded the video, claimed that police were ‘vetting everyone walking onto the bridge’, adding that they were ‘only non-Extinction Rebellion people going about their daily business’.

He wrote on Twitter: ‘I only stopped for a few seconds. It was clear that police did not want the bridge blocked by protestors and so they were vetting everyone that was walking on to the bridge.

‘Most of the XR people were heading towards Millbank, so it was only non-XR people going about their daily business.

‘The woman in the foreground seemed put out that the police officer was asking where she was going.

Alex Armitage, who uploaded the video, alleged that police were ‘vetting everyone walking onto the bridge’ (Picture: @alexjarmitage/Twitter)

‘He wasn’t satisfied with her explanation that she was going to work and asked her to produce her work ID, which she did.

‘The atmosphere felt really tense and intimidating.’

Another person who allegedly got asked for ID claimed the Met Police told him ‘they could stop & search anyone they suspect was intending to cause disruption and check ID’.

When he asked if he could refuse, the officer allegedly replied saying: ‘Yes, if you’re not going on the bridge’.

The allegations spurred outrage online, with hundreds of people claiming the Met had no right to ask for ID.

James Lazarus wrote: ‘They have no right to stop people or demand their ID.

‘Unlawful authoritarian behaviour from the police.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

Jo Owen added: ‘Christ. Checking for what exactly? Deeply sinister.’

UK police have the right to stop and ask a person’s name, what they are doing in the area and where they are going.

However, members of the public do not have to stop and answer any questions.

If they don’t and there is no other reason to suspect the person, this alone cannot be used as a reason to search or arrest them.

Labour’s Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott told Metro.co.uk that if police were requesting ID in the alleged circumstances, it was ‘an infringement of civil liberties’.

She said: ‘In this country we have a long tradition of policing by consent.

‘We do not have a police force or other state agencies who can demand to see people’s ID on a blanket basis.

‘Many people don’t carry ID and it is an infringement of everyone’s civil liberties to demand them in this way.

‘It’s even worse when this is done to clamp down on peaceful protests, and it should not be normalised.’

A spokesperson from the Met Police told Metro.co.uk: ‘The MPS is aware of footage showing officers stopping and speaking to people crossing Lambeth Bridge on Tuesday, 15 October.

Advertisement

‘Officers are fully aware one of the tactics and objectives of Extinction Rebellion is to block the bridges in central London.

‘Officers do not hold the power to force members of the public to identify themselves in these circumstances, and have not been briefed to do so.

‘However, officers on Lambeth Bridge have been proactively engaging with individuals crossing to ensure those with an intention of bringing London to a standstill are not successful in doing so.

‘In some instances, members of the public identified themselves to officers.

‘The MPS has not received any complaints in relation to the conduct of officers on Lambeth Bridge.’

description: Metropolitan Police have come under fire for 'authoritarian' behaviour after allegedly making 'indiscriminate ID checks' on Lambeth Bridge.
